e4: The current policy is inherently deceptive, even if investors are aware of the adjustment. Changing to a new policy upholds ethical financial reporting and minimizes legal risk, ultimately building trust with all stakeholders. While short-term market fluctuations might occur due to investor confusion, long-term corporate health depends on integrity and transparency.
e5: An ethical reporting policy is characterized by transparency, accuracy, and  completeness. It should provide a clear and unbiased representation of the financial performance and position of the company. This includes avoiding any manipulations or distortions that could mislead investors, regardless of their presumed awareness.  Furthermore, such a policy should be consistently applied and readily understandable to all stakeholders.
e6: Yes, I would have several follow-up questions.  Firstly, what specific strategies can Investor Relations employ to clearly communicate the policy change and mitigate investor confusion? Secondly, how will we address potential short-term market volatility and reassure investors of our long-term commitment to transparency? Finally, what steps are being taken to ensure legal compliance and protect against future investigations?
